body:
In GitLab by @asottile on Dec 22, 2019, 09:42

> And only `flake8` is missing this feature.

I mean, not _only_ flake8, I can find plenty of other linters which don't do this ;) -- and while it's useful to look at precedent in others I don't believe it's _the reason_ it should happen.

until we fix our configuration story I don't want to take on a feature like this (especially because it would depend on the configuration)

caching is also very very difficult to get right and flake8 is pretty fast right now (sure if you add 30+ plugins it slows down quickly though)

the example in flakehell is broken, it doesn't handle changing commandline or configuration options

In GitLab by @asottile on Dec 22, 2019, 09:43

that said, make it into a concrete proposal and I'll probably say yes -- where the cache lives, what the cache looks like, what invalidates the cache, etc. is important here

In GitLab by @sobolevn on Dec 23, 2019, 03:04 Good question! Let's dig into it. > where the cache lives I guess that the cache should live relative to the found config (if it is not a global one). I would say that `.flake8cache` `json`-based file looks like the best option. There might be a problem with `.gitignore`, but we can update global defaults for new projects and list this file as excluded from VCS in the docs. Another option is to hack `__pycache__` or similar. But, I don't like it: these files are removed by different tools at random. It is not reliable. > what the cache looks like, what invalidates the cache We can have a look at `eslint` cache file for an inspiration.

s/comment.spec.ts",[],"/Users/sobolev/Documents/github/wemake-vue-template/template/tests/fixtures/faker.ts",[],"/Users/sobolev/Documents/github/wemake-vue-template/template/tests/fixtures/vuex.ts",[],"/Users/sobolev/Documents/github/wemake-vue-template/template/tests/jest-shim.d.ts",[],"/Users/sobolev/Documents/github/wemake-vue-template/template/tests/pages/index.spec.ts",[],"/Users/sobolev/Documents/github/wemake-vue-template/template/tests/setup.ts",[],"/Users/sobolev/Documents/github/wemake-vue-template/template/tsconfig.json",[]]
It basically consists of several sections: 1. Config hash, so any change to the config triggers full invalidation. The config section also includes all installed plugins and their versions 2. Checked files and their content: new files are checked and cached, updated files are checked and cached 3. Error responses to show for files with violations Any early feedback on this?

In GitLab by @sobolevn on Dec 23, 2019, 03:08

It might be also a good idea to include a baseline to the cache as well. I'll open a separate issue for it.

In GitLab by @sobolevn on Dec 23, 2019, 03:39

Related: https://gitlab.com/pycqa/flake8/issues/602

In GitLab by @asottile on Dec 23, 2019, 05:40

- I don't think it should live in the project folder, that'll require `.gitignore` updates which are very annoying
- configuration hash is not exactly a simple thing today, there's lots of places where the files could live that would need considering
- probably should include the flake8 version itself, and some way to bump that version
- what do we do about unversionable stuff, here's an example where we can't possibly know:
    - run flake8 w/ flake8-mypy -- some failure due to a dependency version
    - upgrade a dependency
    - it shouldn't fail now, but continues to do so due to cache
    - **is this enough to make this proposal impossible?**
- cache invalidation / clean up -- as written it appears the cache grows over time and is never cleaned up, how do we manage that in a sane way?
- let's not couple this to "baseline" or whatever, it's already a pretty complex feature as-is

In GitLab by @ericvw on Dec 23, 2019, 07:04

> until we fix our configuration story I don't want to take on a feature like this (especially because it would depend on the configuration)

I echo a similar sentiment as I am still working through the configuration story :smile:.  Once we get to the point of a decent control flow from options being handled among the configuration files and CLI, it would be easier to take on new features that require configuration.

FWIW, I use `make` with a `Makefile` for taking care of executing tools for the file(s) that have changed.  This also allows me to run multiple tools over the same set of files that have been detected as being changed.

In GitLab by @sigmavirus24 on Jan 23, 2020, 16:33

I would echo @asottile's earlier sentiment.

There are other tools that could be coupled with flake8 and mypy to do this properly (although I have to wonder how wise it is to try to be too efficient with mypy).

In GitLab by @jnoortheen on Jan 14, 2021, 13:00

mentioned in merge request !463
